title: Cat. 139  The Barber’s Shop in the Mews, 1896
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 1391896Way: 106  
Levy: 154  
Transfer lithograph, drawn on fine-grained transfer paper  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, upper right above doorway  
One state; image size: 192 × 120 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 9  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 128, 309  
Posthumous edition: 54 impressions printed by Goulding on 12 January 1904  
Posthumous watermarks: 15, 18, 19, 37, 165, 209, 219, 220, 280, 316  
Stone: erased in 1904  
Whistler-Way Letters: apps. III.2, V.1  
Lifetime Exhibitions: London 1895–96 (in 2d ed. of catalogue only; no. 75, as Barber’s Shop, Avery Row, Bond Street); Chicago 1900b (no. 98)

This image of a modest barbershop was drawn in Avery Row, Bond Street, according to the title under which it was first exhibited. Today, although the New Bond Street area still includes Avery Row, the shop itself has vanished and the mews cannot be identified with certainty. The building would have been only a short distance from the Fine Art Society’s premises at 148 New Bond Street, where Whistler’s lithographs were shown from mid-December 1895 through January 1896. With its large bay window and lively signs advertising “Haircutting,” “Rooms,” and “Cigars,” the storefront must have caught the artist’s eye as he walked in the neighborhood.

Whistler sketched The Barber’s Shop in the Mews on a sheet of fine-grained transfer paper (papier viennois, no. 1), a paper he had used frequently in the past but which he had avoided since 1894. He probably drew the image in early January 1896, for it was a late addition to the exhibition at the Fine Art Society, which closed at the end of January. It was also one of five lithographs added to the second edition of the exhibition catalogue (app. V.1).

Chicago: AIC, ivory laid paper (254 × 195 mm), signed; MWC, cream laid paper (283 × 225 mm), signed. Washington: NGA, ivory laid paper (254 × 195 mm), signed.  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 139, only state. The Art Institute of Chicago, bequest of Bryan Lathrop, 1917.633.

</section>
